course.subject: SCIE
course.name: Scientific Understanding of Our World
course.description: This course aims to provide students an overall scientific understanding of our world. This course will deal with fundamental questions, such as: Where does this universe come from? What is the origin of matter? What is the origin of life? What guides the human behavior? What shapes the development of the human society? What will be the future of this world? Students are expected to have Science background. Graded DI/PA/F.

reviews.author: Eggtart
reviews.title: Take a break between lessons~

reviews.author: klkaa
reviews.comment_content:
An 1-credit course to stimulate thinking about important problems in science and to develop a habit of independent thinking.

The ideas are not too deep, so they're pretty easy to understand even with little scientific background.

Main Topics:
Where does our universe come from?
What is the origin of matter?
What is the origin of life?
What guides human behaviour?
What shapes the development of human society?
What will be the future of this world?

As you can see, this course is mainly about the origin and the future of any components in the universe
reviews.comment_teaching:
One week one 60mins lecture + 20mins open discussion
Quite interesting if you like the topics.

The professors interact with students quite often, making the lecture quite interesting.

The open discussion session is quite thought-provoking and enjoyable for me, although not a lot of students really engage in the discussion.
reviews.comment_grading:
Graded DI/P/F.
70% Attendance
30% Final Exam (MC)
Optional bonus: Project (for those who aim Grade DI)
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignments
Only workload is the final exam and an optional project

The final exam only takes 30 minutes and there are 20 questions. They are easy and you should be able to answer most of them correctly if you have paid some attention during lectures

reviews.author: Johnson162
reviews.title: Nice course
reviews.comment_content: One thing that the course instructor emphasized a lot was that the course did not only teach students what they know, but also what they don't know. It consists of different guest lectures and the content covered was very broad, ranging from particle physics to biology. A timeline was set from the beginning of the universe to the future. Lectures are prepared with content related to a specific point on the timeline, eg: what happened at the very first few seconds of the universe, or ecosystem of the early Earth. The last lecture was a panel discussion on the future of human beings.
reviews.comment_teaching: Almost every lecture you have a different lecturer because most of the classes were guest lectures. Most of the lecturers were fun.
reviews.comment_grading: Just pass or fail. Whether you pass the course depends on your attendance. Sign sheets were provided.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload, unless you consider attending classes is a kind of
workload.

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.title: Free 1-credit Pass/Fail course with 0 workload
reviews.comment_content:
Short lectures (1 hour 20 minutes every week) about different topics in science like the formation of the universe, Earth and solar system, emergence of life, evolution, plant biology, human brain, human society, etc.

Very basic introductions to these topics, same as high school science or even lower level of difficulty.

Some topics are interesting, others a bit boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: Different lecturer every week. Some lectures are interesting and funny, but a few are quite boring with too many details like plant biology. It can be a bit confusing because the lectures are not always related to each other so the topics can be a bit random from one week to the next.
reviews.comment_grading: Graded P / F / DI. You get P if you attend 80% of lectures. There is an optional essay/report for Distinction.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload. Only 80% attendance required (9 out of 11 lectures).

Optional essay/report if you want DI grade instead of P.

reviews.author: Leoml
reviews.comment_content: It is about how the earth and life and society is formed from big bang. Some biological and physics concepts are covered. Syllabus can be found in other reviews

Attendance 70%, quiz 30%.
Only a short 15 minute mc test at the last lesson, which is easy.
I got DI at last.
reviews.comment_workload: Zero workload. It can be used as gap fillers, you can get inspirations from lessons.

reviews.author: Super Bombman
reviews.title: A good course
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered:
1. Overview: Scientific Understanding of our World
2. Where does our universe come from?
3. Origin of matter: The Standard Model
4. Foundation of the quantum world
5. Origin of different chemical elements
6. Origin of life; Biodiversity and evolution
7. Origin of human being
8. Why are there plants?
9. How does the human mind work?
10. Planet Earth and the ecosystem
11. Development of the human society
12. What will be the future of our world?

The course is designed for both students with or without scientific background. Even you are a student from SHSS/SBM, you can still enroll this course and enjoy the interesting content.

The lecture focused more on the conceptual aspect of the topic rather than technical details.
reviews.comment_teaching:
According to the course outline, the duration of the lecture is 80 minutes and around 20 minutes will be the discussion time. However, most professors can't finish their teaching within 60 minutes. Thus, there is normally 10 minutes for the Q&A section.

Professors will raise a lot of questions during the Q&A section and some of them is quite interesting. I think the questions did give me another perspectives to look around the world.

Some of the content is boring and I did fall asleep during the lecture. Luckily, the professors normally won't punish you for such action :)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme:
(70%) participation
(30%) MC quiz.

You can get a pass by just attending the lesson.
The quiz is quite easy. If you want to get a distinction, you may go through the ppt after every lecture.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is no homework/assignment.

You just need to read through the ppt once before the quiz in the last lecture.

It is just a 1 credit course, just take it easy and enjoy it!

reviews.comment_content:
The topics covered include:

1. Origin of the Universe
2. Origin of Matter
3. Origin of Chemical Elements
4. Origin of Life
5. Origin of Humans
6. Origin of Plants
7. Origin of the Human Mind
8. Origin of the Ecosystem
9. Origin of Human Society

Aside from the lectures that covered the standard model and basic quantum mechanics (Lecture 3-4), most of the contents focus predominantly on the big picture, instead of the fine technical details of specific scientific theories. This course is certainly fruitful for science enthusiasts, but those without a science background would still be able to grasp the contents taught.
reviews.comment_teaching: Each lesson lasts 1 hour and 20 minutes, with the last 20 minutes being a discussion period for students to ask the lecturers questions. Lessons may sometimes end early if no one raises any enquiry. Most professors teach well and welcome all sorts of questions, but one would easily fall asleep if one is simply uninterested in the topics covered.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is comprised of:

-Attendance (70%)
-Final Quiz (30%)

The final quiz is made up of 25 MCs, all of which are extremely straightforward. One can certainly achieve a passing grade by briefly skimming through the PowerPoint Slides an hour before the assessment.

Final Grade: DI
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is virtually non-existent, with no assignment whatsoever. Further readings are sometimes mentioned in the PowerPoint slides, but they are non-essential to the final quiz. Majority of the grading requirements can be satisfied by simply attending all the lectures.

reviews.author: KatherineLai
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
The origin of the universe
Particle physics & nucleosynthesis
Origin of matter & planet Earth
Origin of Life, Biodiversity & Evolution
Origin of the human being
Why are there plants?
How does the human mind work?
Development of the human society*
Planet Earth and the ecosystem*
What will be the future of our world?*

*: not covered due to class suspension

Each lesson a very different topic is covered (in the order mentioned above). Professors specialized in the area are invited to come teach. The content covered is quite board and targeted at a general audience. There is not much technical stuff and is aimed to introduce you to the different topics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As mentioned in the content part, the course is aimed to a larger audience. The professor do a decent job in choosing relatively easy-to-understand concepts and simplifying them so that they could be understood by all students.

The course intended to take a more interactive approach. in the 1 hour 20 minute lesson, it is originally planned to have 20 minutes of discussion at the end. Professors are willing to answer students' questions.

However, during some lessons the professor gets a bit carried away and takes up the whole 1 hour and 20 minutes for the lecture, leaving no time for the professor to respond to the students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading (pass/fail/distinction) is based on attendance and a final exam. Due to school suspension, the "final exam" did not take place as planned, so grading is based on attendance record. Those who attended most lessons would be given a pass.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload at all - no assignments and quizzes.

reviews.author: UEL K.
reviews.title: A stress-free lesson
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers the following topics (based on the timeline) :
1. The origin of the universe
2. Particle physics & nucleosynthesis
3. Origin of matter & planet Earth
4. Origin of Life
5. Biodiversity & Evolution
6. Plants
7. Origin of the human being
8. Development of human society
9. Evolution of ecosystem
10.  Discussing our world future

Each lesson consists of 1-hr teaching + 10-20 mins open discussion. Students & professors are free to chat and debate on some thought-provoking questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructors here come from a wide range of academic backgrounds( as you can see). Instead of talking academic and statistical stuff, they highly focused on the philosophical and conceptual aspects of each fundamental point of our world.

They also welcome challenging questions given by students and professors.

However, it's easy to take a nap once you are out-focused.
reviews.comment_grading:
70% attendance + 30% small MC quiz (at the first 30mins of the last lesson, which covers all the concepts mentioned above)
Typically easy to pass without an effort.
Just enjoy the lecture and be open-minded is enough.

Professor Chang has once made an attempt to form a discussion group, including professors and some registered students. Maybe you can get a distinction if you join them.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload.
You may prepare for the lecture ppt if you wish to ace the MC quiz.
